awd_titl_txt: Fabrication and fundamental understanding of cellulase-mimetic bifunctional solid acids for hydrolyzing cellulose
awd_abstract_narration:
The first step in converting lignocellulosic biomass resources to fuels using the carbohydrate/sugar platform is to form sugars from the cellulose in the biomass. However, efficiently producing sugars from biomass remains a significant challenge. Chemical conversion of the cellulose in the biomass uses enzymes (cellulases) and homogenous acids (e.g. sulfuric acid) to produce glucose, usually in a 2-step process. The required enzymes are currently expensive; and they need restrictive operating conditions (temperature and pH) and take longer time (days) to achieve satisfactory conversion of the cellulose. Homogenous acids have issues such as equipment corrosion, recycling, and wastewater treatment. This project aims to design a novel biomimetic polymeric solid acid catalyst that combines the functions served by the enzymes and inorganic acids currently used in sequence. By mimicking the cellulase/enzyme, the research project will involve fundamental research to design and fabricate bifunctional biomimetic solid acid catalysts for hydrolyzing cellulose to produce the required simple sugars. The integrated education plan of the project will target different levels of students, including high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Special attention will be paid to high school students and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM (minorities and women). New concepts, research findings, acquired knowledge, and innovative technologies will be disseminated to academia, industry, students, and the Public through publications, presentations, and classroom teaching/learning. All these will directly and/or indirectly benefit research, production, education, and policy-making in the area of bioenergy and bioproducts.

The research project will involve fundamental research of efficient, robust, and low-cost cellulase-mimetic solid acid catalysts for producing sugars from cellulose, one of the major components of biomass. The success of the project would promote the production of biofuels from biomass sugars. Using molecular and structural design, the solid acid catalysts will contain two types of functional groups. The first group, the acidic function, such as sulfonic acid, is responsible for hydrolyzing cellulose. The second group, the binding function, will use functional groups such as hydroxyl, carboxylic, halogen, and boronic acid groups. The role of this binding function on the solid acid catalyst is to bring the acidic function of the catalyst to cellulose to enhance the solid acid-cellulose interaction. The two functions of the new catalyst mimic the cellulose-hydrolytic domain and the cellulose-binding domain of cellulose-hydrolytic enzymes (cellulases), respectively. It is expected that the biomimetic functionalization of the solid acids would significantly improve their performance in cellulose hydrolysis. Specifically, the bifunctional and cellulase-mimetic solid acids will be fabricated via a two-step approach. In the first step, a polymer is synthesized from carefully selected aromatic monomer containing the desired cellulose-binding group(s) by Friedel-Crafts polymerization, which will lead to a backbone polymer with porous structure (larger surface area) and cellulose-binding groups. In the second step, the resultant polymer is sulfonated to introduce sulfonic acid as the cellulose-hydrolytic group. The performance of the resultant cellulase-mimetic solid acids in hydrolyzing cellulose will be evaluated. The research focus is to fundamentally understand the relationships between the structural properties (e.g., surface area, porous structure, and functional groups) of the cellulase-mimetic solid acids and their performance in cellulose hydrolysis. Special attention will be paid to the interactions (affinity, adsorption or attraction) between the cellulase-mimetic solid acids and cellulose and the mechanisms and kinetics of the solid acids in cellulose hydrolysis.

por.por_cntn:
Cellulose, a polymer of glucose, is the most abundant natural and renewable resource and a promising alternative to fossil resources for chemical and fuel production in the future. One of the strategies to convert cellulose to high-value products is hydrolyzing cellulose into glucose first and then upgrading the glucose to chemicals and biofuels, which is the so-called sugar platform. Traditionally, cellulose is hydrolyzed to glucose by enzymes (cellulases) or acids. However, enzymatic hydrolysis is currently economically unfavorable and still faces challenges to commercial success. Acids such as sulfuric acid have issues of equipment corrosion, acid recovery, wastewater treatment, and low glucose yield due to side reactions (glucose degradation). To address the issues of acid- and cellulase-catalyzed cellulose hydrolysis, solid acid catalysts for cellulose hydrolysis have received increasing attention. Solid acids have a solid framework with surface acidic sites to catalyze the hydrolysis of cellulose. They are not only less expensive and more thermally stable than cellulases but also less corrosive and more friendly to the environment than liquid acids. In addition, solid acids are easier to be recovered for reuse after cellulose hydrolysis. However, traditional solid acids have unsatisfactory performance in cellulose hydrolysis mainly due to their insufficient interactions/contacts with cellulose.

Inspired by cellulases, which are highly efficient and selective in hydrolyzing cellulose because of their two-domain structure (cellulose-binding domain and cellulose hydrolytic domain), we proposed to design and fabricate bifunctional and highly porous cellulase-mimetic solid acids for efficient cellulose hydrolysis, which include a cellulose-hydrolytic functionality (sulfonic group) and cellulose-binding functionality (e.g., chloride, hydroxyl, and boronic groups). Using a unique technology (the Friedel-Crafts ?knitting? polymerization), the bifunctional solid acids were fabricated by first synthesizing a porous polymeric framework from carefully selected monomers bearing desired cellulose-binding groups and then introducing cellulose-hydrolytic sulfonic group on the framework by sulfonation reaction. Specific objectives of this project include: (1) design and fabricate cellulase-mimetic solid acids from selected monomers with a porous structure and dual functionalities as catalysts for hydrolyzing cellulose; (2) characterize the synthesized cellulase-mimetic solid acids to map and examine their functional groups and physical properties; (3) investigate the performance of the synthesized porous cellulase-mimetic solid acids in hydrolyzing cellulose; and (4) fundamentally understand the performance and mechanism of the synthesized solid acids in cellulose hydrolysis.

With the support of this award and other resources, we fabricated a series of bifunctional solid acids bearing different cellulose-binding groups (e.g., chloride, hydroxyl, and boronic groups). They had superior performance in hydrolyzing cellulose than traditional solid acids because of the presence of the cellulose-binding groups, which enhanced the affinity of the solid acids to cellulose. This project generated three peer-reviewed journal articles and two conference presentations. One postdoc and two graduate students were involved and trained in this project. The findings of the project were disseminated to peers through presentations and publications and also shared with students through class instruction.

The studies in this project indicated that the performance of solid acid catalysts in cellulose hydrolysis is a combined outcome of the structural properties of both solid acids and cellulose and the efficient contact/interaction between them. In general, solid acids with more functional acid sites, a large surface area associated with mesopores, and strong affinity and close contact with cellulose tend to have high catalytic activity toward cellulose hydrolysis. Incorporating more acid sites, creating mesoporous structure, and enhancing the cellulose-solid acid interaction/contact by mix-milling, dissolving cellulose, and introducing cellulose-binding sites into solid acids can significantly improve the performance of solid acids in cellulose hydrolysis. The introduction of cellulose-binding functionality (e.g., chloride, hydroxyl, and boronic groups) to the solid acids enhanced the interaction/binding between cellulose and solid acid and thereby their catalytic capacity of hydrolyzing cellulose. The results confirmed that the presence of the cellulose-binding groups in the solid acids was an important contributor to the outstanding performance of the cellulase-mimetic solid acids in hydrolyzing cellulose.

The outcomes of this project provided an alternative technology to produce glucose from lignocellulosic biomass, which would promote the bioeconomy for producing biofuels, chemicals, and materials from biomass based on the so-called sugar platform. On a broader impact, the bioeconomy could reduce greenhouse gases emission, eliminate current dependence on fossil fuels, promote the rural economy, and improve energy and national security.
